body:
You can't require any of the rails framework files without requiring the top level file.

The correct script is:

```
bundle exec ruby -r "action_mailer" -r "action_mailer/railtie" -e 'puts "OK"'
```

@rafaelfranca I may be missing something, but even Rails does not appear to follow that guidance per se. A generated minimal Rails app includes this in `application.rb`

```ruby
require_relative "boot"

require "rails"
# Pick the frameworks you want:
require "active_model/railtie"
# require "active_job/railtie"
require "active_record/railtie"
# require "active_storage/engine"
require "action_controller/railtie"
# require "action_mailer/railtie"
# require "action_mailbox/engine"
# require "action_text/engine"
require "action_view/railtie"
# require "action_cable/engine"
require "rails/test_unit/railtie"
```

The closest thing to what you describe would be the `require "rails"`, which so happens to make `action_mailer/railtie` work because it includes `active_support`. Should I conclude that `require "rails"` is a catch-all/proxy for `require "action_mailbox"` or any of the other individual libraries?

Furthermore:

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/activejob/lib/active_job/railtie.rb#L4
https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/actionpack/lib/action_dispatch/railtie.rb#L5
https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/actionmailer/lib/action_mailer/railtie.rb#L4

It seems that they all require the library themselves, which seems to contradict your advice.

The problem appears to be that `global_id/railtie` does not actually require its own dependencies (or, likely more accurately, that `rails/railtie` does not). Your suggestion seems to be a workaround for that defect, rather than addressing the actual problem. 


I don't know what to tell you other than what I told. Any file in the Rails frameworks require the top level file of that framework to be required before. `require 'rails'` in the application.rb does that for us. You can't require `rails/railtie` without requiring `rails`.

This specific problem you have is that [`activesupport/rails`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/activesupport/lib/active_support/rails.rb) isn't required in your program. Rails, by design only require that file in the top level file of each framework. We have that structure exactly to avoid cherry-picking common dependencies in all files. `require "rails"` does that for you, as `require "action_mailer"`

Then why does this line exist?

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/actionmailer/lib/action_mailer/railtie.rb#L4

or this:

https://github.com/rails/globalid/blob/main/lib/global_id/railtie.rb#L5

It's incoherent at best. It's certainly misleading, and it was a regression from Rails 8.0. 

And why does this exist:

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/railties/lib/rails/railtie.rb#L6

But not one for requiring: `rails/activesupport/lib/active_support/delegation`?

Consider what you are saying. You are saying that before requiring `foo.rb` you must require `bar.rb`. However, when you look at `foo.rb`, you see `require "bar"` as one of the first lines. That's not consistent.

As far as I understand it, the `railtie` files are *alternative entry points*. That's the way it has always been.

I already explained above. But I'll link directly to the relevant parts https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/666838f8124bc3734e33052c2813b15741c97e24/activesupport/lib/active_support/rails.rb#L5-L11 https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/666838f8124bc3734e33052c2813b15741c97e24/activesupport/lib/active_support/rails.rb#L23

Ok, should I open a PR to remove lines like

https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/actionmailer/lib/action_mailer/railtie.rb#L4

As far as I can tell, those lines are nonsense based on your explanation.

Alternatively, adding `require "rails"` to https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/main/railties/lib/rails/railtie.rb would seem to be consistent with everything else and ultimately result in `active_support/rails` being required at the right time.

There are a lot of wrong things in the requires here, so just removing those lines will not do us any favor.

I think globalid is requring `rails/railtie` before requring rails. Some railties require rails, others don't. This is inconsistent. If we expect railties to not require `"rails"` and just require `rails/railtie` then the fix is what you said. That also means the `require "rails"` in generated applications is redundant.

Taking a step back, how do I reproduce this error in an existing application? What is the application doing that isn't requiring `rails` like you pointed out Rails does?

By the way, it's not that I don't understand your explanation. I do. I'm pointing out what I believe is a problem in the design from a design fundamentals perspective. It's surprising, causing friction, inconsistent, and it's a regression of behavior in a minor version release.

In our case we require railties before we require a common rails configuration. The common rails configuration varies the configuration it emits based on the railties that are enabled. It requires rails itself.

We didn't need to require `rails` ahead of time until 8.1.0 was released. We can "work around" this by changing the order of requires or requiring `rails` ahead of the railtie requires, but as I said, it was surprising and seemed like a defect, especially since Rails itself was internally inconsistent. 

It looked like this:

```
require_relative "boot"

require "action_mailer/railtie"

require "rails_application/development"
```

For us, it works to reorder those two requires... we don't actually have a temporal dependency because we don't check for ActionMailer being defined until rails initialization. Like I said, it was just a surprise to have a failure during a require of what we thought was an entry point.

The goal is to have what I explained. The reality is that we didn't have in the `railties` gem, and the commit linked as trying to make that goal a reality. https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/1db66c0d4e6398876fbe69b0659d1087f6862e9a#diff-a79c10f572ebe2d487fd1ec69eabf45a2cd0e011c7dd74555da695a6f222ae98R6

So, in order to require `rails/railtie` you should require 'rails`. That is correct.

Now, `<frameworks>/railtie` are special like you said. Some people thought they were entrypoints, and so far, they did work being entrypoints. Most of them are implemented as entrypoint (they require the top level file of the framework), and ergonomically I think they should do.

I know what to do with the frameworks inside rails itself, since requiring the top level file of the framework would make it work, but for things like global_id or any other railtie it is hard to make that work since they can't require `active_support/rails`. So, the correct fix is to make the railtie require `rails` before requiring `rails/railtie`. I'll apply to globalid, but I'm sure other gems will not have similar problems.

So, the safe thing to do in your application is to add `require "rails"` before any railtie like we do in `config/application.rb`.

It is even hard to know what other engines/railties will do because the Rails generator itself don't have any of the requires. I guess because we don't consider those entrypoints and they are required after the `require "rails"` line in `config/application.rb`.

I'm fixing the internal railties (all the engines are correct) and `globalid` which would fix your immediate problem, but solving this inconsistency across the community will be hard.

Thank you, I appreciate the reconsideration and addressing it.

I'm curious about the rationale for needing to require "rails" before requiring "rails/railtie", especially given that that loader is actually in a "railtie" gem. It does seem surprising. I can certainly go with it now that the individual library railtie loaders work as entry points again, but I just want to understand better the rationale.

Thank you again.
Btw, I think the community will end up needing to correct the issue in each efferent library since `require "rails/railtie"` now results in an immediate error.

The rationale is that we want to avoid to have to remember to add/remove requires individually into files. The way we do that is to define entrypoints where we can require those shared features. We do that in every single framework. The exception was Railties.

Having requires in individual files was causing a lot of problem when we move or refactor code since it might pass in our test suite but fail in applications depending in the order those individual files are required in the applications/libraries.
BTW, I'm adding tests to make sure those entry points stay entrypoints https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/55973
That's great, thank you. And thank you for the additional explanation.
